title: Former silk's Mystic Journey to the Cox Plate
text:
The retired senior counsel’s excitement is contagious.

Trainer Adam Trinder (left) and Wayne Roser take the spoils earlier this year. AAP

Mystic Journey was purchased under the advice of trainer Adam Trinder for just $11,000, and has gone on to win 11 of her 16 starts, and a staggering $3.5 million in prize money.

Roser is quick to emphasise this is no overnight success – he and Trinder have been buying carefully selected, reasonably priced horses for some time.

But he never imagined a Cox Plate was possible.

“You see horses that cost a million dollars that can’t win a maiden around provincial Victoria – you never know what the engine is going to be like,” he says.

“She’s just an exception. As they’ve said, she’s probably the best horse to come out of Tasmania.”

The story of Roser’s career is almost as spectacular as that of his horse.

Advertisement

He left school aged 14, and it was only after he was married and had family that he returned to night school to get his HSC while working full time.

“You went for a job and they used to say, where’s your bit of paper?” Roser recalls.

He scored a place at the Australian National University studying law and eventually became one of Sydney’s top silks.

“It’s a bit like racing really. You start off a solicitor, and you never know where that goes, you just work hard.”

The Enfield case, which came towards the end of Roser’s career in the law, was particularly memorable.

In February 2009, the Einfeld was sentenced to two years jail for perjury. Three year's earlier he was caught speeding, but rather than accept the $77 fine at a court hearing in August 2006, Einfeld said a friend, American college professor Teresa Brennan, had been driving.

Only problem was Brennan had died three years earlier.

The case was similar to the Cox Plate – a high pressure battle.

Advertisement

“There was a lot of behind-the-scenes pressure about what should happen, but … you stick by principles and what you think is right and wrong,” Roser says. “You go by that, not by outside noises and influences.”

Disgraced former Judge Marcus Einfeld arrives at court with his head bowed in 2009. AAP

Roser has brought that same philosophy to racing. He and Trinder have faced criticism at times for not running Mystic Journey in certain races and for not replacing Darmanin with a higher profiled jockey.

But Roser’s loyalty to his team is unbreakable; he heaps praise on Trider repeatedly.

“He’s just a genius. He works 24 hours a day, seven days a week, and that’s what you want.”

Roser retired to the Apple Isle after ill health cut short his career in the law. He’d long owned a property in the seaside village of Sulphur Creek, and during his legal career he often used it as a haven where he could work on big cases.

His love of horses was born on grandfather’s dairy farm when he was a kid. “I spent a lot of time down there riding bareback, minding the cows basically. I followed racing but the ownership came in much later. It’s a costly game actually.”

Mystic Journey will take on one of the most even Cox Plate fields in years. While the dominance of champion mare Winx scared away rivals in the past four editions of the race, her retirement has seen horses from Japan, Ireland, France and New Zealand target the race.

Advertisement

Such was the competition for spots that three-time group one winner Humidor, who twice ran second to Winx in her Cox Plate wins, is only an emergency and unlikely to get a start.

Roser says the Moonee Valley Racing Club’s decision to guarantee hand-picked international horses, places in the Cox Plate field, has cost local gallopers their shot at glory.

“It’s a real dilemma at the moment for racing: How many international horses do we bring over? There’s got to be a level to allow Australian horses to participate, because they create racing for 12 months of the year.”

On Saturday his horse will carry the hopes of the local industry as the best Australian-bred horse in the race.

Roser says it will be stressful – but in the best possible way.

“This is what dreams are made of – you just can’t describe it really.”
description: The incredible life story of retired senior counsel Wayne Roser could get even better after Saturday's Cox Plate.
